text: There will always be naysayers in your workplace. Do not let them influence you.
Some questions I ask at interviews: is there a qa process, code reviews, continuous integration? Describe the product and product teams?
Take notes about everything during interviews. It will help in understanding the company and improve interview performance.
There are always the naysayers in a team. Don't let them influence your judgement.
You have more power than you think. Don't give it up so easily.
There is no need to be different for the sake of being different. Know objectively why being different makes a positive difference.
Do not be afraid to close unresolved tasks. Sometimes they may never be completed.
New developers are likely to replicate the same quality as the existing codebase. Quality code is likely to replicate itself to success.
Using a new technology is meaningless if you do not know why you are using it.
There is no need to try everything. Focus on a goal and research potential paths to obtain the goal.
Avoid the fallacy of multitasking yielding more productivity. Total output does not increase simply by working on many things at once.
In your project, don't plan for the "maybe they will want this" requirements. Plan for the concrete requirements first.
Learn the context and follow up with appropriate demands
Taking every single opportunity is just as bad as taking zero opportunities.
Maintaining a normal schedule not only works in survival situations, but also helps for delivering quality code in intense situations.
Stick to the highest standards, whether it is your own or the company's.
What experiences apply to the job? Everything.
There are huge productivity benefits to co-location.
When frustrations with people arise, maximize the human interaction. Don't minimize it.
There should be little reason to run live tests if you have comprehensive logging systems.
It is possible to be too cooperative with your team.
Delegate? Empower.
Credibility with your internal team is just as important as credibility with external customers. Don't cry wolf when there is none.
If anyone labels a new feature request as an "emergency" they are lying. #relativity
Copying bad code from other projects is convenient, but still bad.
Urgency is relative.
Being busy can be a bad thing.
It is a red flag for a company or team when everyone is too busy to be bothered.
Start with models your team already knows and introduce changes slowly.
Sort be feature, then objects.
The eternal battle between asking for help or doing it yourself.
Don't kid yourself; GUI tools are more convenient than command line.
Even though you can organize files by directory structure, it still helps to have unique filenames across the entire project.
A professional opinion is still an opinion. #everyonehasone
It is impossible to understand 100% of the codebase

No change is minor
It is not enough to have a standard directory structure. Having a standard filename convention helps too.
I used to love primary key columns. Now I hate them. Starting to prefer natural keys.
Sometimes it pays to spell out every detail no matter how condescending the description may sound.
Try to handle the lowest level of exceptions as much as possible. It keeps the code clearer and easier to follow.
Confusing code begets confused developers who, in confusion, contribute more confusion to the confusing code. #confusing
RT @angelamelick: It's impossible to unsubscribe from LinkedIn email updates, isn't it >:(
Private methods are the easiest to refactor.
Always think twice before copying and pasting exact snippets of code.
Always delete unused code/files when checking in your work. It avoids future confusion.
Preferred java date beans in descending order. Joda time, java.util.date, java.sql.date.
The easier it is to unit test the more inclined people are to test. Have a solid testing infrastructure and tests will quickly follow.
Don't rely on data quality when coding.
Sometimes it is hard to tell the difference between picking at bad code versus nitpicking.
Choose your first job wisely. It will become the foundation to your professional career.
Even in development, know your audience when writing.  A user will not care about your technical buzzwords.
Just because someone wants to work until midnight every day does not mean you have to do the same.
It is possible to have too many levels of abstraction. It is also possible to abstract too much that your code loses all context and meaning
Remember to plan out a testing phase for your releases.  Many developers and tech leads forget about this crucial step!
When you work for an organization, it is good to have organizational skills.
It's easier to believe than to think. Think about why new technologies and methodologies would benefit your team. Don't just believe in them
A good trick is to focus on an underlying goal when planning each release rather than have a potpourri of random changes.
Just fixed a bug by accident.  I feel like a superhero.
When cleaning your cubicle with 409, wear gloves.  That stuff burns.
Work is a lot like multiplayer online gaming.  You get your fair share of trolls and try-hards.
Do not underestimate words.  They are powerful.
Chile rellenos are my weakness.  They fuel me for coding.
You can't just promote employees randomly.  You have to find replacements to fill in their previous jobs.
Never forget about the users, no matter what kind of development you do.  Back-end changes ultimately affect the user.

The "can-do code ninja hacker" attitude is useless without planning and forethought.
Project management is a full-time job, but many developers take it lightly. I wonder why that is.
I always thought usability was intuitive to everyone since they most likely have used several programs in their life time.  I was wrong.
Having a good front end/UI designer is essential.  Many development teams focus on the back end, but presentation is important!
